channel.title: Files on Thumbs
channel.description: Recent content in Files on Thumbs

item.title: Evolution
item.author: user@example.com (Hugo Author)
item.description: TODO How did animals evolve to have opposable thumbs? How did we evolve to have longer and stronger thumbs? We initially had short thumbs and long fingers to swing on branches. Longer thumbs would get in the way, but after our ancestors stopped climbing trees, this was no longer a problem. Our ancestor's thumb strength and length initially had variation. However, having longer and stronger thumbs granted better grip strength and dexterity, allowing the usage of complex tools and weapons.

item.title: Genetics
item.author: user@example.com (Hugo Author)
item.description: What are some traits in thumbs that can be passed down from parent to child? A trait that is passed down from parent to child is the hitchhiker's thumb. Hitchhiker's thumb is a trait in human thumbs that allows people to bend their thumbs back further than being straight (picture below). While it is often regarded as a simple Mendelian trait, it is not actually that simple, as we will see below.
